Students: James Heineman, Michael Calderone, Joshua DePetro, Jonathan Barr
Title: Affordable Sustainable Roof
Abstract: The goal of this project was to design and assess the value of an innovative roofing system that integrates a green roof with solar panels and a water collection system. Through research and testing, we were able to determine the thermal, drainage, weight, and solar properties of our roofing layers in order to conduct a life-cycle cost analysis for use on residential homes. A wood truss with a polygonal top chord was designed to support the roof structure.

Title: A Study on Biologic Healing in Enzyme Modified Concrete
Abstract: The goal of this project is to study the bond between concrete and a biologically induced concrete repair. Concrete is the most common building material in the world, but it has a number of problems relating to its durability. It is susceptible to cracking and degradation, and the United States is already billions of dollars behind on repairing and replacing concrete infrastructure. The repair uses enzymes, carbon dioxide, and calcium chloride to precipitate calcium carbonate. The solution heals cracks by returning strength and reducing permeability. The bond between the repair and the concrete is not well studied, so the goal of the project was to study durability and characteristics of the repair using scanning electron microscopy.

Title: How Wildfires in California Should Be Fought
Abstract: The Humanities and Arts Requirement was completed with a sequence of courses in History and English that culminated in a research paper in a seminar on Global Studies. This paper examined the history of wildfires and discussed existing firefighting techniques and new technologies implemented in the fight against wildfires. The conclusion of this paper is that new technology and current strategies need to be used together to fight wildfires most effectively.
